text: is a prefecture in the Chūbu region of Japan on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Chūbu" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 126. The capital is Kanazawa.Nussbaum, "Kanazawa" at p. 467. == History == Ishikawa was formed merging Kaga Province and the smaller Noto Province.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. == Geography == Ishikawa is on the Sea of Japan coast. Toyama Prefecture and Gifu Prefecture are on the eastern border of the prefecture. The southern border of Ishikawa meets Fukui Prefecture. The Noto Peninsula is in the northern part of the prefecture. The southern part is mostly of mountains. Kanazawa is in the coastal plain. The prefecture includes some islands in the Sea of Japan, including Notojima, Mitsukejima, Hegurajima. ===Cities=== *Hakui *Hakusan *Kaga *Kahoku *Kanazawa (capital) :*Komatsu :*Nanao :*Nonoichi :*Nomi :*Suzu :*Wajima ===National Parks=== National Parks are established in about 13% of the total land area of the prefecture.Japan Ministry of the Environment, "General overview of area figures for Natural Parks by prefecture"; retrieved 2012-3-13. ==Shrines and Temples== Shirayamahime jinja and Keta jinja are the chief Shinto shrines (ichinomiya) in the prefecture. "Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 3 ; retrieved 2012-2-9. ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan * Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art * 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art, Kanazawa ==References== == Other websites == *Official Ishikawa Prefecture website ,
title: Ishikawa Prefecture
